text: Psalm 3
A Call to Yahweh in Distress

A psalm of David at his fleeing from the presence of Absalom, his son.\f + \fr Ps 3 \ft The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one \f*
Yahweh, how many are my enemies;
many \add are\add* rising against me.
Many \add are\add* saying about my soul,
“There is no deliverance for him from\f + \fr 3:2 \ft Or “in” \f* God. \qs Selah\qs*\f + \fr 3:2 \ft Meaning uncertain; probably a musical or liturgical direction \f*
But\f + \fr 3:3 \ft Or “And” \f* you, Yahweh, \add are\add* a shield around me,
my glory and the one who lifts up my head.
\add With\add* my voice I call to Yahweh
and he answers me from ⸤his holy hill⸥.\f + \fr 3:4 \ft Literally “the hill of his holiness” \f* \qs Selah\qs*
I lay down and slept;
I woke up because Yahweh sustains me.
I am not afraid of the ten thousands of people
who all around have set themselves against me.
Rise up, O Yahweh; deliver me, O my God;
for you strike all my enemies \add on the\add* cheek.
\add The\add* teeth of \add the\add* wicked you break.
To Yahweh belongs deliverance;
\add may\add* your blessing \add be\add* over your people. \qs Selah\qs*
